passages.text: North America United States
Financial Brokers, Asset Managers & Exchanges
Industry Brokers Asset Managers & Exchanges
We hosted 5 companies at the DB Tech Conference

At the 2025 Deutsche Bank Tech Conference on August 27- 28, we hosted investor meetings across three companies within our broker, asset manager, and exchange stock coverage. These included the two recent IPOs for which we launched coverage in June, eToro Group (ETOR- Hold) and Circle Internet Group (CRCL- Hold), as well as Nasdaq (NDAQ- Buy). We also hosted fireside chats with executives from two private companies in the crypto space: Kraken and Blockchain.com.

Participation from the management teams included: eToro's Head of Global Investor Relations Daniel Amir, Circle's Head of Capital Markets & Investor Relations John Andrews and Investor Relations Director Matthew Oil, Nasdaq's SVP of Investor Relations Ato Garrett and AVP of Investor Relations Matthew Moon. We also moderated fireside chats with two private companies - Kraken's co- CEO David Ripley, and Blockchain.com's Director of Business Strategy and Corporate Development, Nita Contreras.

Overall, our main takeaway from commentary from these companies is that the pace of adoption around crypto assets and blockchain processing rails is increasing both within institutions and retail investors/traders/consumers.

From an institutional perspective, we see a rising pace of interest from traditional financial institutions (TradFi), to explore development of blockchain- oriented digital product solutions, especially within the stablecoin arena, as outlined by CRCL mgmt.

Within retail, mgmt, teams discussed dynamics around increasing demand for trading & investing in crypto assets, via a wide range of user types, from novice traders/investors to more professionally- oriented active investors.

Thus, although in very early innings, we see a rising convergence between TradFi and DeFi (decentralized finance) within our coverage sectors, that have the potential to drive major changes in the financial ecosystem, and potentially across an array financial sectors.
Investors at the conference were also focusing on a myriad of nuances around these
Brian Bedell, CFA Research Analyst +1- 212- 250- 6600
Son Nguyen Research Associate +1- 212- 250- 9311
Companies featuredeToro (ETOR.QQ), USD44.40HoldNasdaq, Inc (NDAQ.QQ), USD95.24BuyCircle (CRCL.N), USD130.94Hold
Source: Deutsche Bank

broad industry trends, attempting to gauge the realistic size of the addressable markets, potential winners and losers, and the magnitude of the pace of change, along with risks for that pace to hasten or slow. Thus we see the investor debates across these themes becoming increasingly active in both the near- term and longer- term, which should create greater investor interest in these sectors over time.
Following are some key takeaways from the investor meetings of our covered companies:

Since coming public and especially since the passing of the GENIUS Act, mgmt. is seeing a substantial increase in interest from a wide range of traditional financial institutions in looking to develop infrastructure that embraces the usage of stablecoins. This is coming from a wide array of use cases, ranging from creating greater efficiencies in remittances & cross- border and peer- to- peer payments, to developing alternatives within B2B and B2C payments functions, to exploring usage in institutional collateral to funding crypto asset trading & investing activity (the latter of which still accounts for more than half of industry stablecoin activity).

The sheer magnitude of the number of announcements of significant partnerships is removing some of the investor concerns (at least for now) around the addressable market potential for stablecoins, as well as the potential for USDC to gain share of industry stablecoin circulation. Already, growth in USDC circulation is tracking well at \(\) 70.6\(billion, up from\) \ \(61.5bn\) at \(\) 6/30\(and\) \ \(60.1bn\) at \(3 / 31\) (and already exceeding our recently raised \(\) 9/30\(estimate of\) \ \(70.1bn\) . Mgmt. expressed optimism around the potential for more partnerships to be forthcoming, while also saying the recently announced partnerships will need to show traction in USDC growth to reinforce the validity of the announcements.

Still, industry fragmentation remains a key debate, especially as to what extent financial institutions (both TradFi and DeFi) will seek to develop their own proprietary stablecoins and blockchain architecture. This said, mgmt. views the Circle platform as being a much more efficient outsourced solution for these financial institutions, and though it remains to be seen what portion of the industry will choose to partner with Circle, or develop their own solution (or even partner with other stablecoin issuers), mgmt. thinks the lack of substantial traction for other stablecoin issuers so far, is evidence the market will remain in a more concentrated state, as opposed to much greater fragmentation (and USDC's market share has increased to \(29.0\%\) from \(27.2\%\) at \(6 / 30\) and \(28.5\%\) at \(3.31\) ).

There were mixed views on the outcome for RLDC (reserve less distribution cost) margin as USDC grows. On the one hand, mgmt. reiterated its expectation for the RLDC margin to begin to stabilize over the next 12- 24 months (from a \(39\%\) level in 2024 to \(36 - 38\%\) in 2025 and an expectation to begin to plateau in 2026- 27 (though no specific guidance given). However, should compelling opportunities for major institutions to elect to outsource with Circle arise (at higher distribution costs), it would not be inconceivable for the RLDC margin continue its downward trend for some time, because any future partnership deals (including large ones) would likely be quite accretive to EBITDA margins, and thus attractive from that P&L perspective, as well as further enhancing USDC's market share, thus strengthening the industry concentration argument.

Mgmt. also cited quite significant potential to take market share from Tether's USDT over time, although acknowledging USDT would likely retain a substantial share of industry circulation over the long- term. But mgmt. believes USDC will be making progress in this endeavor in the next 2 as TradFi firms are likely to seek more highly regulated stablecoin solution (favoring USDC), evidenced by the lengthening list of Circle TradFi partnerships and addition, new partnerships, such as the one with Binance, incentivizes that it to steer more stablecoin toward USDC (currently at \(\sim\) 38bn within Binance) vs. the current larger share of USDT (currently at \(\sim\) 30bn at Binance).

Mgmt. also expressed excitement around major new innovations that they believe will consolidate more industry share to Circle. This includes the Circle Payments Network (CPN) which has begun to see cross- border payments activity, and should scale nicely over the next 12 months (client onboarding with careful KYC diligence is currently a bottleneck for now). Mgmt. is also very excited about the new Layer 1 Blockchain, Arc. Mgmt. views this new blockchain as potentially becoming an industry standard for stablecoin usage, with faster speeds, better security and privacy, and a strong validation system. Mgmt. believes Arc will be especially attractive to TradFi, and conceptually has more centralized features vs. the typical decentralized features of most blockchains.

Combined with these new innovations, mgmt. sees a wider array of potential areas to generate fees. These include small transaction fees around on/off ramping (mostly redemption fees), converting to other stablecoins rapidly, or even potentially switching from a tokenized money market fund (USYC) to USDC, when yield- seeking holders of USYC would seek to liquidate into USDC to make payments. In addition, mgmt. sees further developer integration, along with various areas to earn fees within CPN and Arc, as well as any fees from providing white- labeled infrastructure to other stablecoin issuers, as bolstering the fee revenue growth case over time.

Overall, the commentary provided some comfort to us in our forecasts, where we assume annual growth in USDC over 2024- 27 that is double mgmt's baseline assumption (so growing at \(80\%\) per annum vs. mgmt.'s \(40\%\) "assumption" - and to be clear, while mgmt. is expressing optimism, they are not specifically endorsing our forecasts). We also forecast more pressure on RLDC margins than mgmt. is assuming within its broad commentary, with a view that they will engage more heavily in solidifying partnerships, to grow USDC. We also believe fee revenue growth will outstrip their assumptions, and we even think our fee revenue growth assumptions may be conservative, at over \(80\%\) next year and over \(90\%\) in 2027.

Mgmt discussed the US expansion strategy in some detail, including rolling out Copy Trading in 4Q in the US, with the expectation of obtaining an RIA license in 1H26. The license is key, because it will enable ETOR to compensate professional investors for Assets under Copy, as the investors become licensed under the firm's RIA designation. This will also cover professional investors outside the US, from which US investors would also be able to copy upon licensing. Some \(70\%\) of ECC (Equities, Commodities, Currencies) volume is related to copy trading.

We see the rollout of Copy Trader in the US as quite promising, though mgmt. stated it remains to be seen how quick the acceptance would be - and could easily take at least 6- 12 months to start to scale. One dynamic that remains uncertain is eToro's
29 August 2025 Brokers, Asset Managers & Exchanges Brokers, Asset Managers & Exchanges

brand awareness in the US, which is much lower than in other regions, especially Europe and the UK. Thus, mgmt will need to decide how aggressive it wants to be in marketing spend, which we think could drive some upward pressure on expenses, considering the much larger TAM in the US, and ETOR's differentiated platform.

Mgmt. also views acquisitions as potentially part of its US growth strategy, given it could expand the firm's current account base significantly (currently \(\sim 300k\) accounts in US), and enable cross- sell of the Copy Trading protocol as well as a wide array of other asset classes (including over 100 crypto coins listed and smart portfolio asset mgmt products). Other potential expansion areas could focus on developing more capabilities that would drive earning assets higher, such as savings products, and further leveraging its AI capabilities (including in the long/ short smart portfolios).

Mgmt cited good progress in the business broadly, including in 3Q so far, which was not well understood by investors following the 2Q earnings call. Crypto trading in particular remains strong, and the firm continues to progress well on adding customers. The "normalization" commentary cited on the call simply referred to trends being more similar to May & June, vs. the benefits from the elevated market volatility in April (though without monthly precision, this cadence was difficult for investors to ascertain).

Mgmt. acknowledged expenses are tracking above initial views, given the growth opportunities across geographies, especially given the interest in retail trading and eToro's product offering globally. Mgmt. reiterated an expectation for 3Q operating expenses to be flat with 2Q, hence around \(\) 137\mathrm{mn}\(this is above our current estimate of\) \ \(130\mathrm{mn}\) , which we forecasted after 2Q earnings on our forecast at the time for revenue to be down \(5\%\) in 3Q vs. 2Q).

While current EBITDA margins are in the mid- 30s, mgmt. strives to expand this to over \(40\%\) by 2030. While this may appear conservative, mgmt. does expect an expansion of marketing spend in the US, which could be at least a 1- 2 year endeavour before scaling the US more substantially.

Mgmt. realizes the investment community would like more disclosure of a variety of metrics, to enhance modeling capabilities and conviction on growth trends. Thus, mgmt. may start producing monthly metrics later this year, which could be enhanced over time to add granularity. This would include more detail around trading volumes and interest earning assets, and potentially organic asset growth further down the road. We think these disclosures could be very well received.

Mgmt reiterated trends around fintech revenue growth, citing Verifin remains in the 20s, and there could be the typical seasonality in 4Q for contract renewals & professional fees in Calypso that could bolster 4Q revenue. There were no updates to any fintech revenue guidance for 2025, the most recent of which post 2Q earnings includes: Capital Market Tech revenue at the low end of the medium- term target of high- single/low- double digit growth, Regulatory Tech revenue well within the medium- term target of high- single/low- double digit growth, and Financial Crime Mgmt revenue at the low end of the medium- term target of mid- 20s growth.
Mgmt stated that corporate decision makers have become accustomed to the

ongoing level of uncertainty around macro outlooks, particularly impacts from any major changes in global trade policies. Thus, the delay in decision making and contract signing seen earlier in the year across fintech and workflow & insights, has since normalized a few months ago, and that current dynamic remains in place.

Mgmt. remains focused on expanding its array of options vehicles, including O- DTE & shorter expires on single stock options, which could expand from Mag 7 stocks. The index options franchise also continues to gain traction, now in a \(1.0 - 1.5\%\) market share range, with revenue still relatively small but growing nicely. Should index options grow as a portion of options trading overall for NDAQ, it would expand revenue capture rates given the higher pricing of index.

While delistings remain a headwind on listing fees, IPO activity has been accelerating and the pipeline/backlog is growing which could help counter the headwind dynamic. That said, there is no change to 2025 guidance for listing fee headwinds.

Mgmt. continues to target annual operating leverage, with intermediate- term Solutions revenue targeted at an \(8 - 11\%\) annual growth rate vs. \(5 - 8\%\) total adjusted operating expense growth. Growth in trading volumes could augment this calibration, with strong trading volume and revenue growth backdrops potentially driving expense growth higher in the range (also depending on Solutions revenue growth) and vice- versa in weaker trading volume and revenue backdrops.

With mgmt. hitting its deleveraging debt/EBITDA target much sooner than expected (by 16 months), mgmt. continues to evaluate the ROI potential on stock buybacks vs. debt paydown, remaining opportunistic between the two. Still, although investors certainly like share repurchase, further deleveraging could also be well received, with debt/EBITDA ratio currently at 3.2x.

Our PT is based on where we think CRCL will trade at the end of 2026, using a P/E multiple of 42.5x on 2027E (based on a weighted mix of 7 comparable stocks), and discounting back to 12 months from now (September 2026), with an annual discount rate of \(12.7\%\) using CAPM model (assuming an annual S&P 500 return of \(10\%\) and a risk- free rate of \(4\%\) ). Upside risks are: 1) faster adoption of stablecoins, 2) concentration of stablecoin market share into key players, including Circle and USDC, 3) lower distribution costs than expected, 4) less substitution of tokenized money market funds vs. stablecoins, 5) higher interest rates, and 6) better- than- expected cost control. Downside risks are: 1) slow industry adoption of stablecoins, 2) fragmentation of stablecoin market share reducing growth potential of USDC, 3) higher distribution costs than expected from pressure from distribution partners, 4) worse- than expected substitution of tokenized money funds vs. stablecoin usage, 5) lower interest rates, 6) risk of systemic shocks and mass redemption of stablecoin, 7) more significant expense growth than expected, 8) any major systems failures and operational challenges that reduce user confidence in stablecoin and USDC, and 9) risk of inability to effectively monetize transaction flows and fee streams.

ETOR (eToro Group - Hold Rating)Our PT is based on where we think eToro will trade a year from now, based on our 2026 EPS estimate. For our 12- month price target, we are using a forward P/E that is in line with the S&P 500 on our 2026 EPS estimate, due to our view of potentially more variable earnings results in at least the near- to- intermediate term. Downside risks are: 1) any significant reduction in customer adoption of social investing and Copy Trading protocol, 2) lower trading volumes across equities, currencies, commodities and cryptoassets, 3) much lower than expected revenue per trade across key products, 4) lower net interest contribution, 5) higher- than- expected expenses, 6) more severe regulatory and litigation risks than expected regarding trading protocols, 7) rising competition in major trading businesses across key global markets, 8) risk of customer attrition and users incurring severe losses within the platform, 9) any potential dilution or integration risk from future acquisitions, and 10) any major systems failures that reduce user confidence in trading and investing at eToro. Upside risks are: 1) better- than- expected traction in user adoption of social investing, across key global markets, including the US, 2) much stronger trading volumes than expected, especially in cryptoassets, 3) much better revenue per trade from more effective monetization of customer trading orders, 4) stronger organic growth from new products and initiatives, 5) much better- than- expected net interest contribution from higher net revenue yield and interest earnings balances, and 6) accretive acquisitions.

NDAQ (Nasdaq - Buy Rating)We value exchange stocks by assigning a P/E to our 2026 EPS estimates a year from now, based on relative P/E premiums/discounts to historical trends. Our 12- month price target is based on our forecast for NDAQ to trade, a year from now, at a forward P/E that is a 20% premium to the P/E of the S&P 500, which is at one standard deviation above its 3- year average relative P/E, given an improving EPS growth profile. Downside risks are: 1) a major slowdown in the revenue growth of the newly acquired businesses along with more significant earnings dilution from the deal than anticipated, 2) weaker- than- expected recurring revenue broadly, 3) a prolonged slowdown in trading volumes, 4) any onset of a much more hawkish regulatory stance on exchange market data & related functions or any market structure proposals that would be adverse to exchanges, 5) any major systems failure at NDAQ that reduces investor confidence in trading at NDAQ, and 6) higher expenses or less operating leverage than expected.
The Equity Rating Dispersion Chart depicts the following:

The proportion of recommendations that are rated "buy", "sell" and "hold" over the previous 12 months. This is shown for securities issued in the stated region e.g. "Europe Universe". See rating definitions below. This is represented by the "Companies Covered" bars in the chart. The percentage value displayed above the bar is the proportion as a percentage. E.g. \(50\%\) above the "buy" / "Companies Covered" bar means that \(50\%\) of DB's equity research covered companies over the past 12 months have a "buy" rating.
Next to each of the three respective bars showing the proportion of "buy", "sell" and "hold" recommendations we provide two additional bars to show:

- The proportion of "buy", "sell" or "hold recommendations where Deutsche Bank and or/Affiliates provided MIFID Investment or Ancillary Services in the past 12 months. This is represented in the "MIFID Investment and Ancillary Services" bar. The percentage value displayed above the bar shows the proportion of Companies Covered with the given rating where DB has also provided MIFID Investment and Ancillary Services in the past 12 months. E.g. \(50\%\) above the "Cos. w/ MIFID Investment and Ancillary Services" bar means \(50\%\) of the Companies Covered with the rating stated have also received MIFID Investment and Ancillary Services from DB.

- The proportion of "buy" (or "sell" or "hold) recommendations where Deutsche Bank and or/Affiliates has provided Investment Banking services in the past 12 months for which it has received compensation. The percentage value displayed above the bar shows the proportion of Companies Covered with the stated rating where DB has also provided Investment Banking services in the past 12 months. E.g. \(50\%\) above the "Cos. w/ Investment Banking relationship" bar means \(50\%\) of the Companies Covered with the rating stated also have an Investment Banking Relationship with DB.
Buy: Based on a current 12- month view of TSR, we recommend that investors buy the stock.
Sell: Based on a current 12- month view of TSR, we recommend that investors sell the stock.
Hold: We take a neutral view on the stock 12- months out and, based on this time horizon, do not recommend either a Buy or Sell.
TSR = Total Shareholder Return. Percentage change in share price from current price to projected target price plus projected dividend yield
Newly issued research recommendations and target prices supersede previously published research.

Macroeconomic fluctuations often account for most of the risks associated with exposures to instruments that promise to pay fixed or variable interest rates. For an investor who is long fixed- rate instruments (thus receiving these cash flows), increases in interest rates naturally lift the discount factors applied to the expected cash flows and thus cause a loss. The longer the maturity of a certain cash flow and the higher the move in the discount factor, the higher will be the loss. Upside surprises in inflation, fiscal funding needs, and FX depreciation rates are among the most common adverse macroeconomic shocks to receivers. But counterparty exposure, issuer creditworthiness, client segmentation, regulation (including changes in assets holding limits for different types of investors), changes in tax policies, currency convertibility (which may constrain currency conversion, repatriation of profits and/or liquidation of positions), and settlement issues related to local clearing houses are also important risk factors. The sensitivity of fixed- income instruments to macroeconomic shocks may be mitigated by indexing the contracted cash flows to inflation, to FX depreciation, or to specified interest rates - these are common in emerging markets. The index fixings may - by construction - lag or mis- measure the actual move in the underlying variables they are intended to track. The choice of the proper fixing (or metric) is particularly important in swaps markets, where floating coupon rates (i.e., coupons indexed to a typically short- dated interest rate reference index) are exchanged for fixed coupons. Funding in a currency that differs from the currency in which coupons are denominated carries FX risk. Options on swaps (swaptions) the risks typical to options in addition to the risks related to rates movements.

Derivative transactions involve numerous risks including market, counterparty default and illiquidity risk. The appropriateness of these products for use by investors depends on the investors' own circumstances, including their tax position, their regulatory environment and the nature of their other assets and liabilities; as such, investors should take expert legal and financial advice before entering into any transaction similar to or inspired by the contents of this publication. The risk of loss in futures trading and options, foreign or domestic, can be substantial. As a result of the high degree of leverage obtainable in futures and options trading, losses may be incurred that are greater than the amount of funds initially deposited - up to theoretically unlimited losses. Trading in options involves risk and is not suitable for all investors. Prior to buying or selling an option, investors must review the 'Characteristics and Risks of Standardized Options", at https://www.theocc.com/company- information/documents- and- archives/publications. If you are unable to access the website, please contact your Deutsche Bank representative for a copy of this important document.

Participants in foreign exchange transactions may incur risks arising from several factors, including the following: (i) exchange rates can be volatile and are subject to large fluctuations; (ii) the value of currencies may be affected by numerous market factors, including world and national economic, political and regulatory events, events in equity and debt markets and changes in interest rates; and (iii) currencies may be subject to devaluation or government-imposed exchange controls, which could affect the value of the currency. Investors in securities such as ADRs, whose values are affected by the currency of an underlying security, effectively assume currency risk.

Unless governing law provides otherwise, all transactions should be executed through the Deutsche Bank entity in the investor's home jurisdiction. Aside from within this report, important conflict disclosures can also be found at https://research.db.com/Research/ on each company's research page. Investors are strongly encouraged to review this information before investing.

Backtested, hypothetical or simulated performance results have inherent limitations. Unlike an actual performance record based on trading actual client portfolios, simulated results are achieved by means of the retroactive application of a backtested model itself designed with the benefit of hindsight. Taking into account historical events the backtesting of performance also differs from actual account performance because an actual investment strategy may be adjusted any time, for any reason, including a response to material, economic or market factors. The backtested performance includes hypothetical results that do not reflect the reinvestment of dividends and other earnings or the deduction of advisory fees, brokerage or other commissions, and any other expenses that a client would have paid or actually paid. No representation is made that any trading strategy or account will or is likely to achieve profits or losses similar to those shown. Alternative modeling techniques or assumptions might produce significantly different results and prove to be more appropriate. Past hypothetical backtest results are neither an indicator nor guarantee of future returns. Actual results will vary, perhaps materially, from the analysis.

The method for computing individual E,S,G and composite ESG scores set forth herein is a novel method developed by the Research department within Deutsche Bank AG, computed using a systematic approach without human intervention. Different data providers, market sectors and geographies approach ESG analysis and incorporate the findings in a variety of ways. As such, the ESG scores referred to herein may differ from equivalent ratings developed and implemented by other ESG data providers in the market and may also differ from equivalent ratings developed and implemented by other divisions within the Deutsche Bank Group. Such ESG scores also differ from other ratings and rankings that have historically been applied in research reports published by Deutsche Bank AG. Further, such ESG scores do not represent a formal or official view of Deutsche Bank AG. It should be noted that the decision to incorporate ESG factors into any investment strategy may inhibit the ability to participate in certain investment opportunities that otherwise would be consistent with your investment objective and other principal investment strategies. The returns on a portfolio consisting primarily of sustainable investments may be lower or higher than portfolios where ESG factors, exclusions, or other sustainability issues are not considered, and the investment opportunities available to such portfolios may differ. Companies may not necessarily meet high performance standards on all aspects of ESG or sustainable investing issues; there is also no guarantee that any company will meet expectations in connection with corporate responsibility, sustainability, and/or impact performance.

numerical_data.context: rice target is based on our forecast for NDAQ to trade, a year from now, at a forward P/E that is a 20% premium to the P/E of the S&P 500, which is at one standard deviation above its 3- year average
